captions.text:
Good morning John. This video is for young
people in America. You are not a young person

in America, but you can still watch. In fact,
please do, and if you feel compelled to, send
this video to young people you know in America.

It's time to talk about why we're not voting.
Here are some of the reasons I hear.

"I don't want to get jury duty." STOP. No.
NO. Nothin' - no correlation between those

two things. You get jury duty whether or not
you're registered to vote.

"I don't want to vote for the lesser of two
evils." Why - why not? It's the lesser of

two evils. Do you want to vote for the greater
of two evils? Because not voting is like half

a vote for the greater of two evils. Also
I just did my absentee ballot and I felt a

lot of times like I was voting for the greater
of two goods. It happens.

"I don't know who or what to vote for." This
is a completely acceptable excuse. However,

if you care about the world, it's really easy
nowadays to do research on the ballot initiatives

and candidates on your ballot. Just google
the place where you live and "voter information

packet" or "candidates." Do a little research.
It'll take like a half hour. Also don't feel

bad for not voting on every single thing on
the ballot. Here's something from mine: "To

change the name of the State Auditor to Commissioner
of Securities and Insurance.'" I don't care
about that.

"I don't even know if I'm registered." Allow
me to introduce you to canivote.org. It will
tell you in like twelve seconds.

"I'm not registered." Eleven states including
California have same day voter registration,

and even in places that don't, there's still
time to register. You can check out how in
the links in the description.

"I don't really care." This is completely
acceptable; if you don't care don't vote.
It's, like, one of the good excuses.

"Big corporations and millionaires are the
only ones who actually decide the outcomes

of elections." Big corporations get fewer
votes than you do, and millionaires get the

exact same number. However, millionaires do
disproportionately affect elections because

99% of them vote! If you want proof that millionaires
can't buy elections, there it is for ya. They

go to the polls and they vote because they
know that is the only way people get elected.

"I can't get to the poll on November 4th."
Another completely legitimate reason, and

I'm sorry to hear that, and look into absentee
boating next - boating? Absentee boating - is
not something you want to do.

"I'm just done with this, the gridlocks and
bickering and cynicism - I just don't want

to be a part of it." I feel you. I absolutely
do. Campaigns these days seem to be more about

energizing the base in the form of angering
and terrifying them than they are about actually

talking about issues or providing information.
This tends to turn away more moderate voters

- especially young people. But the more moderate
voters are the ones that we need to turn this
country away from partisanship and gridlock.

"It's not even a democracy." OH MY GOD, YES
IT IS. You know how many democracies there

were in the world in 1900? ZERO. There was
no universal suffrage in the entire world.

We could do better in America. It could be
more representative. In fact, there are ballot

measures in lots of states designed to make
it less representative. The only way to make
it more representative is to vote.

And finally, the one that bugs me the most:
"You know my vote's not going to matter."

The notion that your vote won't matter because
it probably won't be the individual deciding

vote in a particular election is a magnificent
failure of imagination. If every young person

who used this excuse got off their butt and
voted one Tuesday every two years, they would

literally be the deciding vote in thousands
of elections. So maybe it's time to do that.

To recognize that the power lies with us.
That's what democracies are.

Make this country better because you can,
so you kinda have an obligation to. People

born after the year 1980 make up like 30%
of the electorate now. But only 21% of people

under the age of 24 are expected to vote this
election. If you aren't voting, no one is

hearing your voice, so they have no reason
to represent you. There's only one way you

can change that and it is a very easy thing:
vote.
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

title: Ten Terrible Reason to not Vote (and two good ones)

comments.text:
if you vote, then you have no right to complain as what you're doing is 
stating "I believe the system works, and since it is fair, the appointed 
has every right to be there and i accept it". if you believe your vote 
counts (re: presidential/general elections), you really need to do your 
homework and find out how the system really works. all you need to do is a 
little maths to find out how ridiculous the belief that your vote can 
change anything especially as often as Hank claims it could. a millionaire 
who wanted to affect the outcome of an election would not do so by casting 
a single vote! he would have a vast array of options available that we 
don't that would affect it in a more decisive way than voting. most people 
i know don't even know what a referendum is. i spoke with people after the 
uk general election and i was shocked at the idiocy of some of the people 
who voted. one conversation went something like this - "did you watch the 
election?" "no i don't follow politics" "so you didn't vote then?" "oh no - 
I voted" "so who did you vote for?" "cameron" "which of his policies do you 
identify with" "i don't know what his policies are". really? 
I'll just leave you to ponder this. both parties goals in the long run are 
identical, voting gives you the illusion of choice, the only choice you are 
given ultimately is the SPEED at which their goals are realised. I'll 
illustrate it with this example: (I'm going to simplify the figures a 
little to make it easier to grasp, and i can't remember the exact amounts) 
Labour in power University tuition fees were £1500 p/y 3yrs = £4500. tories 
got in, hiked prices ridiculously to £9000 p/y £27000. Eds' proposal should 
he win: a drop to £6000 p/y = £18000. do you get it yet? imagine tories had 
never got in, and Labour hiked the price up from £4500 to £18000, what 
would happen? the only difference is time has passed, Labour back in, and 
can basically say, "we didn't raise the price, we lowered it, we did you a 
favour, we're the good guys"

they try to convince you they're Roses. wake up and smell them for 
yourself. I'm sure you'll find it kinda smells like Bullshit.﻿
comments.author: Gamblor404

comments.text:
I think there is one simple reason why the US has such a low voter turnout: 
Because the option not to vote exists.

Down here in Australia, we have mandatory voting, with strict enforcement. 
If you don't show up or make a postal vote, and you can't give a damn good 
reason for your lack of participation, you get fined $20. Refuse to pay 
that fine and it will be upped to $170.

Our voter turnout on whatever Saturday gets picked for election day? 95% or 
more.﻿
comments.author: Roxor128

comments.text:
I'm Hank Green and I want your money. Just give me your money, that's all I

comments.author: Fred Norris

comments.text:
My name is Brian Boyko. I hate to say it, but reason "Elections are 
controlled by the rich" doesn't mean what you think it does. It means that 
candidates require money to run campaigns; they are dependent upon the 
funders of those campaigns. It is a democracy responsive only to 
millionaires because any candidate must win a "money primary" to even be 
viable.  This is not an excuse for apathy - I am actively working to change 
that. But it is a viable reason not to vote - voting has no statistical 
influence on what policies get passed.  Funding campaigns, does.﻿
comments.author: Brian Boyko

comments.text:
I'm having trouble deciding who to vote for at the next general in my 
country (England), so i came here to get some Vlogbrothers advice.

My problem is that the three main parties, The Conservatives, Labour and 
the Liberal Democrats, are almost entirely interchangible.

I've read their manifestos, and it really is a matter of 'which almost 
identical empty promise do i choose?'

Each party's leaders has made a series of promises that are very clearly 
just hot air, just like their promises at the last election. 

For example- 8 billion of extra funding to the NHS, but no idea where it'll 
come from. The idea that a mansion tax will pay for everything in the 
country and pay off the deficit by next Thursday. The idea that lowerung 
tax on the upper 1% by another 5p is a good idea.

David Cameron has even said he will create enough jobs for everyone that 
wants to work- if he's that good at his job, why didn't he do that four 
years ago?

The fringe parties are in some ways worse. The SNP are tories pretending to 
be labour. UKIP are racist, bigoted idiots with a manifesto that would 
destroy our economy and healthcare systems, as well as break EU law. The 
Green Party are so far left wing they're actually right wing.

And that's the problem. I want change. For too long England has had 'more 
of the same' politics, no matter which party was in charge. But the fringe 
parties are all bat-crap crazy. The Green Party have the most policies that 
I agree with, but they have some that genuinely scare me.

I don't want to vote for 'more of the same', but I can't vote for change 
bacause the outliers are terrifying.﻿
comments.author: James Bennett

comments.text:
Voting isn't just the simple act of marking a ballot on Election Day. It is 
a statement of principle. When you vote, you grant to others power you 
don't have. Do you claim to have the right to take $2,800 a month from my 
family and spend it as you please? Would you do so yourself? If so, you're 
a thief. If not, you're a hypocrite. Because, when you vote, you purport to 
grant this power you do not have to others. When you vote, you are a thief 
by proxy.
By what right do you do this? Can you even articulate your reasoning for 
this action that is so antithetical to freedom? I dare you to try. You 
might surprise yourself with the answer.
When you vote, you participate in the theft and extortion of yourself and 
others. When you vote, you are an accessory to theft, extortion and all the 
crimes perpetrated by the beast of government. Your vote is what gives 
legitimacy to the illegitimate.
The conclusion is inescapable: voting is an immoral act. It defies reason 
and incriminates the voter in all manner of transgressions -- not unlike 
holding down a victim while your neighbor has his way with her. It's 
detestable and I see no reason to ever participate in it unless I choose to 
be a criminal too.
There are only two answers to this problem: embrace being a thief or don't 
vote. For me, the only answer is don't vote.

Paradoxically Speaking, Voting isn't just Immoral in itself, it's the 
ass-clowns we got running in Government, who do the same things over and 
over again, and as Einstein said "Keep doing the same things over and over 
again successfully (for the better or worse) and it will produce the same 
results"  

People condemn politicians for thinking only in terms of self interest and 
what’s in it for me. But what is in the hearts and minds of most voters 
when they are deciding which party to support? Yes, precisely: self 
interest and what’s in it for me. If that is our motivation
when we vote, we will, and do, create that reality by electing politicians 
who reflect in their actions the very state of mind that we used to give
them their power. If you want to change the kind of politicians that 
represent us, change yourself. If people still think it is worth voting in 
today’s rigged system , then let us vote for what we believe is right and 
not only for what we believe is right for us, materially, in the short 
term. Then, if this is done by enough people, we will have politicians that 
manifest that state of mind.  I Personally was Going to Vote for UKIP, 
HOWEVER when i found out there was Racist and made up of old Labour 
members, i thought "Forget about it" So Remember Voting is not itself 
immoral, however Today's Rigged or corrupt system, it is.  Personally I'd 
Vote for Monks!  we need a lot more Karma and peace in the world, Monks are 
More Educated than they let on, Spiritually and Scientifically, and 
Politics needs to be erased, and set up a Spriritual-High Council. if we 
was to think in terms of Future-rism we would know this is what they will 
be doing, and the sooner we move towards these goals, the sooner a better 
future will be upon us!﻿

Here's one possible reason. Votes in the U.S.A are not counted by number

voted for said party so if the amount of votes a state has is based off of 
the amount of registered voters then your vote could go to the other party.﻿

equation.﻿

comments.text:
It's weird how voters think that non-voters complain a lot. How about the 
voters themselves? They complain about the politicians they voted. Well, 
it's their fault for voting for those politicians. We, non-voters, should 
not complain if our hopes of changes won't come true? Fine. But, you voters 
should not complain if the politicians you voted for disappoint you.﻿
comments.author: Daan892

comments.text:
If we want to make changes, why should we be dependent on politicians? In 
the end, they will disappoint us anyway. Besides, it's our dream for 
changes. We should be the ones who make them come true, not other people. ﻿
comments.author: Daan892

comments.text: Right, it's a republic ﻿
comments.author: radioactivated the gamer

comments.text:
Everything that you said was true... in America.
You only get two choices (three, if we count not voting to be a choice).
Go down this comment to see a list of the political parties in Bulgaria (I 
live there).

Did you see it?
Good.

Now try to imagine watching all of the candidates and listening to what 
they have to say. It's literaly impossible. Even if it was, it's still 
impossible to know witch are the ones that aren't lying to get votes.
The choice usually goes down to one of the 4 or 5 parties that are rich 
enough to afford an actual campaign - comercials, tv shows, etc...
The problem is... those parties shouldn't be having that kind of money! 
It's really obvious that they have really powerfull (and probably really 
shady) sponsors. Voting for them would mean voting for those sponsors, that 
no one says nothing about.

So... if you were a bulgarian, how would you vote? Would you vote for one 
of the small parties (witch are going to lose spectacularly, and whose 
votes will automatically be devided among the winners), or one of the 
winners, and it's anonymous sponsors.

----------------
Here's the list (it's probably not the full list, but you get the idea)
(Also - it's on bulgarian, but It's not really important to read it anyway. 
It's just a list of names.)
http://bg.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%8A%D0%BA_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B8_%D0%B2_%D0%91%D1%8A%D0%BB%D0%B3%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%8F
﻿
comments.author: Alexander Dinkov

comments.text:

comments.author: SaMant1s

comments.text:
Actually, a recent study showed that public opinion in the US had no effect 
on policy, but the opinion, desires, and locations of the money held by 
millionaires had a near one-hundred percent efficiency rating in changing 
policy. The authors of the study came to the conclusion that we were indeed 
an Oligarchy.﻿
comments.author: BioLegacy141

comments.text:
I kinda gave up on voting for justice when my country heard that one 
candidate was gay and voted him out of the election. Haven't voted since 
because I was so pissed off.
This Friday the government in Finland will decide if gay marriage will 
finally be legal. It's been downvoted so many times. The last time was one 
week before Pride week. Like a slap on the nuts to all LGBTQ.

#tahdomme2014 ﻿
